segments.text: This is Martha Hunt interviewing Dr. Jane Sell on Women in Academia.
Dr. Sell, how long have you been teaching?
At Texas A&M?
Well, and any college.
Okay, well I taught for three years when I was a graduate student, and we had responsibility for two courses when you're a graduate student.
You know, you teach it on your own.
It's an individually taught course.
And then here, I've been here since 1978, so that's...
Okay, and where did you go to school for your graduate and your undergraduate?
I went to the University of Wisconsin for my undergraduate degree, and I went to Texas A&M for my master's, and I went to Washington State for my Ph.D. And what made you decide to become a professor?
Well, I wasn't sure about really what I wanted to do at all when I first entered the master's program.
And even all through the master's program, I wasn't sure.
But near the end of the time, I got really interested in a specific area, you know, experimental social psychology.
And then when I, you know, I decided that's what I wanted to go into.
And then when I went into the Ph.D. program, I developed this, what I describe as a passion for it.
And I really enjoyed teaching, and that's what I wanted to do.
I mean, I just discovered that I wanted to do it.
And, um, were you married at the time when you were getting your PhD, or were you married after you came in?
No, I, uh, yeah, I got married in 1980 after I'd been here for three years.
Was it hard choosing between a family and a career, or was that choice necessary?
I don't think, a lot of people I think are faced, a lot of women are faced with that kind of dilemma, I think.
But for me, since I had waited so long to get married, it became more of a matter of organization.
But I think, I think in the beginning, I think there is kind of a choice sometimes, but I think that you can do both if you try to
assure yourself that you don't have to be a superwoman, that you realize that you have limits on the time that you have and you try to organize it.
I think it's very hard for people to go through graduate school and have a family.
I mean, I'm imagining that it would be hard.
I can't imagine, you know, doing that.
But I think since I was
had been in the field and had been a professional for a while and had a little more experience, that was a lot easier in terms of organization, but it's not easy.
No, it's not.
I mean, you have to really organize your time.
And what is your definition of a liberated woman?
It means a lot of different things to a lot of different people.
Sometimes people use it derogatorily.
When they say a woman liber, usually if you use the word liber, that's more of a derogatory kind of term.
And so some people think that it's a person who is feminist in that they attack men and so forth.
Well, I don't think that that's at all what it is.
A real feminist is a person
who thinks about the issues in terms of gender roles.
I mean, that's what I would think.
So it's hard to say, when people say, are you a feminist, you never know really what that means.

So if you're talking about what I think a feminist is, I think it's a person who is concerned with the issues about gender roles in our society, who thinks about them, who is concerned for the liberation of, liberation in the sense of
freedom for both men and women in terms of rigid sex roles.
Now was your question, do I consider myself a feminist?
Well, that's the next question.
Do you feel that you are a liberated woman?
Well, like I said, the word liberated woman can mean a lot of different things.
I feel like
I believe that there should be less rigid gender roles, something we talked about, you know, I just mentioned.

I think that society, in terms of the economic structure particularly, doesn't allow that to happen as much because, for example, we don't see men having the same kind of rights with children as women are given sometimes.
And the opposite view is women are still discriminated against in terms of child care kinds of facilities.
So I think that
society forces that kind of rigidity in terms of gender roles.
I mean, there's something individuals can do about it, obviously.
I mean, since I'm a social psychologist, I believe that.
But I think that we're nowhere near getting to a really flexible society.
You can see, look around and see societies that are really more flexible than ours in terms of the kinds of arrangements that are made for couples to take care of their children.
And I don't think the United States has gotten to that.
And sometimes it scares me.
I think we're going backwards rather than forwards in some of those kinds of issues.
But I think academia is one place where you really can achieve a little more freedom in terms of those
rigidity of roles because you have a lot more freedom over your time.
So that's one thing that's really helped us.

I mean, my family, my husband, and my child and I because, for example, today, Friday, Phillip stays home and then I come in and then I, you know, we take turns some days and then three days she's with a sitter.
And that kind of flexibility is wonderful because it allows sort of everybody at least some kinds of times away and then times there so we can sort of
have more time with her than we would if we had to put her in, say, an institutional kind of child care facility.
But not very many people have that kind of freedom.
That's a real luxury.
If you're outside of academia, you don't have that.
So we're really lucky in that respect.
And I know that most people don't have that kind of freedom.
And that's what I think is bad in terms of family development and freedom and feminism, all those kinds of issues.
Moving away from the family and kind of into your work, do you feel that you had to work harder to get where you are today than your husband or other male colleagues because you're women?
Well, that's a hard question.
Maybe in some ways, yes, and in some ways, no.
I think that there's a basic socialization
process that women sometimes have to overcome.
Not all women, of course, but many women, because a lot of us are socialized to think in terms of family orientation period.
And I come from a fairly traditional kind of household.
And my parents were not all that eager to see me continue in my education.
and go so long without a family.
In fact, they sort of gave up hope about a family.
So I mean, there's that initial socialization that's very hard to overcome and I think stays with us a lot, a lot of women.
You know, why am I doing this any time?
And sometimes when it gets tough, when the going gets tough, you think, gosh, if I, you know, maybe my parents were right, maybe I should just give this all up and stay home.
Or sometimes when you feel guilty about not spending enough time at home, you think about those kinds of things.
So there's that initial socialization.
Once I, professionally, however,
There are sometimes problems in terms of acceptance initially, and I think that that's tougher on women than it is on men.
So when you first meet people, for example, there is this kind of idea that you do really have to overcome, in some sense, being a woman to show that you're professional.
Of course, that's a horrible thought.
It doesn't happen with women, among women, by the way, but it does sometimes when you're with men.

Now I notice that less now, and maybe that's because I've become a little more established in the discipline, but I noticed it a lot initially when I was very young, where you had to sort of overcome both the stereotype of being young and a woman.
And so that was sometimes a problem.
Do you feel that you received less encouragement for your achievements because you are a woman?
You were talking about your parents and things like that and being socialized.
As you were going through school or when you first became a professor and first started working, did you feel that your colleagues did not encourage you or your family did not encourage you?
Well, my family.
was always emotionally encouraging, but it was sort of not really encouraging professionally, but always emotionally encouraging.
It just was sort of like, well, why do you need to do that kind of attitude?
So there was that.
I don't feel that professionally, especially in this department, I don't feel like I was discouraged at all.
I didn't feel that at all.
And in graduate school, I had a wonderful experience with a professor there who gave me a lot of his time and was very encouraging to me personally.
Now, there are always problems, or there are sometimes problems with that when you become very close with a professor and the professor is a male and you're a female.
Sometimes there are a lot of innuendos that go along with that.
But in this case, there wasn't so much of that just because this character was so kind of,
different that no one would have thought about that kind of relationship.
Have you ever had any other problems with sex roles or men coming on to you or whatever because you're a woman working?
Has that been a problem?
Sure, I mean, sure, you have that kind of thing happen, but I don't know whether that's a problem because of the status of being in a position.
I think that's a problem that all women have to deal with.
You know, it's an irritation, and it can be sometimes very frustrating that that happens, that people see you that way instead of professionally when you're expecting to be seen one way.
But I think that happens to all women regardless of position.
And that's the thing that women...
have to confront, I think.

Did you ever feel that male colleagues avoid you or feel that what you have to say is unimportant or that what you're doing as far as research or your teaching is just not important because you're a woman or that you don't quite know, you don't quite have the knowledge that they do?
I don't really think so.
I haven't felt that.
And as I mentioned before, I think sometimes initially that happens.
But my feeling here is, and of course that may be because I wanted to feel that way, but my feeling here is no, that that's not what has happened.
Now, I have sort of a minority view in sociology because I'm an experimental social psychologist and that's fairly rare.
And so sometimes
I won't get kidded about that as a minority opinion, but I don't think that has anything to do with my gender.
And I've never felt, at least after an initial, very initial stage, I've never felt that they've taken me less seriously.
What have been some of the problems in your private life due to your career or with your family?
Have you felt that there's been anything?

well first let me say I think for the most part it's been just the opposite that because I'm so happy in terms of what I do because it's such a joy to me that that only is good things for my quote private life and actually it turns out that it's almost inseparable you don't really talk about your professional versus your private life it seems very much intertwined to me so that for the most part it's only been good because I'm so happy with what I'm doing in terms of time I mean there's always the problem in terms of time and you have to

prioritize what you're going to do, and as I mentioned before, I think you have to be fairly well organized, so for example, we're lucky, I think we're lucky in that our little girl goes to bed at 7.30, which is early, and so that leaves time later on to work, and so we even, you know, we switch around times, who's going to stay home, or who goes in, or if we spend time together, so it's led to more planning in terms of organization, but
You know, and there's that kind of a dilemma maybe.
And since this is not just a full-time job, it's really more than a full-time job, it's led to pressures in terms of time.
And sometimes it gets to be pretty overwhelming.

Sometimes in the middle of cleaning the house when you should be grading tests, or in the middle of grading tests when you should be cleaning the house, it sometimes, you know, gets pretty overwhelming.

I think, again, I think that's probably a real common problem, and for the most part, it's been good that I'm so happy professionally, that I really enjoy what I do, because I think if I didn't, it would be tougher on my family.
I think it would carry on.
Does your husband really encourage you in your work and in your research?
I mean, does it help with him being a professor and understanding?
Yeah, I think it definitely helps, yeah.
It would be, he's very encouraging.
to me, and I'm encouraging to him.
And that's what makes, I think, a good relationship.
It would be, I can't even imagine, I think it would be very difficult, if not impossible, if you had someone who was not at all encouraging about what you wanted to do.
But again, I think that's because both of us realize that that part of our lives is so important, and we're so happy with the kinds of things that we do.
Do you feel that you've ever had a problem getting things published because you're a woman?
Well, I think I've had problems getting things published, but I don't think it's because I'm a woman, no.
In fact, I don't think that...
I can honestly say I don't think that's ever made a difference.
Okay, good.
What times in your life have you felt discrimination?
Have there been times when you felt you've been discriminated against?

Well, as I mentioned earlier, I think still, initially, there are problems in terms of when you first meet people, sometimes professionally, in terms of them taking you, quote, seriously, if you're a woman.
Although in our discipline, that's less.
And in our department, by the way, because we have so many women, I think that that's become much less of a factor.
In the University of Hull, of course, there are a lot less women overall.
And so I imagine the less women they are, the more
different they are and therefore the more the heavier the stereotypes probably are.
So I'm sure it's a problem elsewhere.
And the things that all women encounter, I think, in terms of discrimination.
When you go to a store, for example, and people ask you for your husband's name versus your name.
Those kinds of issues, I think, that all women have.
Other than that, as far as special,
kinds of issues that I would face that maybe other people in different positions wouldn't.
I don't really think so, except, as I mentioned, that initial kind of
you know, meeting with someone or initial interactions.
Do you feel that this people's response to you initially when they first meet you, before they get to know you, do you think it's because it's initially or because you're a woman?
Like, do you feel like men have the same problem that when they first enter a new, you know, workforce, whatever, they have to overcome this?
No, of course, both of those factors are important.
Just being new, for example.
But I'm talking about something a little more insidious, more...
social-psychological.
We know that when you first meet someone, you don't have any information about them.
And so what happens is that what we call diffuse status characteristics are the first things you notice.
Like, of course we first notice whether they're male or female.
And the question is, how much does that organize the interaction?
And I think that in our society still, that organizes the interaction to a great deal.
And not all of that, of course, is something we want to get rid of, but some of it is, I think.
And what I'm saying is that

when you meet somebody first, and I'm not just talking about first interactions, I'm even saying over a period of a couple weeks or so, that that seems to have an overwhelming effect, so that what you get sort of, you know that this is happening, and so you have sort of the idea, yes, I have to be especially good at this, or especially eloquent, or especially something to overcome that initial stereotype that, oh, well, she's, quote, just a woman.
Okay.
In the 50s, women were viewed as stereotyped as being intuitive, emotional, independent, while men were viewed as intelligent and independent and rational.
How do you feel about this?
Has this changed over the past few years?
Do you feel women are still viewed as emotional?
That's almost an empirical question, and there have been studies on that which demonstrate that, in fact, yeah, those stereotypes still do exist.
In some areas they've weakened, but in some areas they haven't weakened at all.
I mean, in some of those stereotypes.

So, yeah, the recent studies all indicate that as far as power, influence, and all of those variables that we've talked about in terms of social psychology, that, yeah, gender is still a very important characteristic and still organizes interaction.
Have your achievements made you feel less feminine or less desirable as a woman?
Do you feel that because you're a professor in this high status role or whatever, that that's made you less of a woman?
Not at all.
Women tend to hold lower expectations of what they can do and accomplish.
Why do you feel this occurs?
Did you ever have feelings that because you're a woman you had to work harder and you might not be able to accomplish what is set for you?
Well, this gets to some of the social psychology literature on the subject about expectations and self-expectations versus other expectations.
And we know that through interaction that you can develop, of course, expectations for yourself.
That's the old self-fulfilling prophecy and labeling and all that kind of stuff.

and that suggests that very early socialization is especially important so your parents if your parents hold very traditional views or that women can't do this or should do this or whatever then you're more likely to respond to those kinds of labels and if teachers and peers and so forth have that same kind of labeling process you're likely to respond to it so i think
Yeah, I think a lot of women are subject to that.

Still, as much as we say, well, things are changing, they may be changing, but I don't think they're changing all that rapidly in terms of the kind of curriculum and stuff that are offered in schools.
And a lot of it depends on individual teachers, of course.
So that early socialization is very important in terms of shaping what you expect that you can do and what you can do.
So we have, again, lots of studies that seem to indicate, yes, women
or men, or in terms of race and ethnicity and so forth, that a lot of things are shaped very early on, and sometimes those are hard to change.
Now, what was the second part of the question?
Did you ever feel these feelings, or have you ever felt that you couldn't accomplish certain things, that you had to work harder to accomplish these things because you were a woman?
I think the insidious part of labeling is that you don't think it's because you're a woman necessarily.
Well, you might do that, but you may think it's because it's you, whatever you, you know, is.
So I think a lot of women have the idea, well, I can't do this as well as other people, and the other people may be mainly men in that case.
So, yeah, I can, I mean, I remember feeling that,
in elementary school, in junior high, high school, all of that, really through college.
When I was an undergraduate, I initially chose a very traditional kind of career.
I was in secondary education.
And I felt a lot of that.
I mean, I remember thinking, well, what's a good career for a woman?
I remember going through a lot of that.
And I was backed up by my family.
And I can't really pinpoint what exactly changed that.
except that, you know, achieving some sort of success in other kinds of areas, you know, in college.
College was an exciting experience for me because, you know, I just learned so many really different things that I hadn't learned before.
So I think, yeah, the process itself is hard to pinpoint because it's so diffuse, but I think a lot of people experienced it, especially women, but not just women.
I think in terms of ethnicity and race, you'll find
those kinds of things happen too, and individuals too in terms of personality.
Have you ever felt isolated because you were a woman?

I think sometimes when there are not other women around and you'd really like to talk to another woman just because you'd like to, because you feel like you want to talk to someone like that, yeah, you can feel very isolated.
And that's why I think we're lucky in this department that we have women that we can talk to about this.
Or sometimes, of course, if you have just good friends, even if they're male, even you can do that.
But I remember, especially when I first came here, feeling very isolated in terms of just wanting to talk to somebody.
So I think having other women around, not in maybe any organized fashion, but someone to talk to and bounce ideas off of is very important.
How have you found that men and women are evaluated?
Do you feel that, say in this department, men and women are evaluated equally?
I think that in terms of performance and so forth, I think that they are.
may sound sort of Pollyannaish, but I think that they really are.
Now there are some, there is sexism here because

I think we have people who went through the same socialization system that a lot of us did, so that there are, of course, you know, some ideas about, well, the little lady, you know, that kind of stuff.
But I think when it comes down to it, when it comes down to evaluating performance, I think that it really is done fairly, fairly, fairly fairly.
Women seem to be more competitive with each other than with men.
Do you...
Do you feel this, that you're more competitive with the women in this department than with the men?
No, I think that's a myth.
You think it's a myth?
I mean, there have been some ideas about that.
There's an old concept called the Queen Bee Syndrome, and the Queen Bee Syndrome was the idea that once a woman made it,
that she sort of looked down on other women, sort of the idea that, well, I made it, and I worked really hard, and you guys are just, you know, you do it on your own if you want to.
I'm sure not going to help you.
And for a while, that was sort of popularized, I think, in the literature.
But they haven't been able really to find much evidence of that since then.
At least that's my understanding.
You could check with Liz.
She might know something about that.
But I don't feel that at all.
I've never felt that, I don't think.
When you arrived at A&M, when you first started working here, not as a graduate student, what women's organizations were on campus?
Do you remember?
On campus, there was the University Women's Organizational Group.
I'm not sure of the full title.
And I attended a meeting of theirs a long time ago.
and just was not really interested too much.
I mean, it wasn't that I didn't find what they were doing so interesting, but quite frankly, I was so busy then.
I mean, literally all my time was spent just working and teaching and doing all that kind of stuff, so I didn't get involved as much.
I think now there are more groups and more support groups, and I think that's really good.
Are you a member of any women's organizations?
None that are solely for women, no.
Okay, because, like, have you ever been a member of NOW?
Yes.
But that's not solely for women.
But it's a women organization.
Right, I mean, but I thought you meant like a support group for women.
No, I was a member of NOW.
I'm a member of NARAL, which is the...
I won't be able to remember, but it's for pro-choice kinds of issues, which is not, again, not just a women's group.
I'm also a member of ACLU, which is both, and a member of Amnesty International and a couple other groups of similar kind of nature, but they're, yeah.
Okay.
What types of changes do you feel that have occurred in favor of women at A&M since you've been here?
Or what changes that haven't occurred would you like to see occur?
I think the most important thing is that more women be hired.
And that's been a change in this department.
When I came here, there were

three of us i think and now we have seven women on the faculty so that's been a big change and since i was involved in the recruiting i know it didn't have anything to do with trying to recruit women it was just of course who the best candidates were and i think that's what will happen i mean i think more and more women will come here but um i think a m still has a very conservative image
And when talking about encouraging women to come here, sometimes you have to think about what kind of support they're going to get when they do come here.
For example, there are only nine female full professors at this whole university, and our department has two of them.
So when you think about going over, let's say, to the Ag school, where there probably are none, I'm not for sure, but there are very few women
I think there are a couple women, but I don't think there are any focal places, then you have to consider what kind of atmosphere they're going to be faced with.
And I think generally that's an important issue, because I think some areas are more subject to the kinds of stereotypes we talked about and the kind of discrimination than are other areas.
So that's the most important thing, I think, to get more women here.
And I've seen that's been one change in this department anyway.
I'm not so sure about overall, although other departments in liberal arts, I think there are more women.
More women are getting into the administration.
I'm saying that's an important issue, I think.
So, for example, one of the associate deans in liberal arts is a woman, and Grace Chisholm in the president's office is a woman.
And so that's been important, and that I see more in a growing awareness of the issue.

I think that A&M, quite frankly, is way behind the times if we just look at the issues about the recognition of gay rights and the women in the band and issues like that, which seem almost Neanderthal when you look at it.
I don't think, however, those issues are necessarily reflective of the students' attitudes.
What I seem to pick up on growing acceptance, or maybe I just wish to pick it up, but I think a growing acceptance of women in terms of...
integration into society in general.
And I think a lot of that is because we have a lot more women and the women themselves are important in that respect.
Earlier you talked about our being socialized as a woman and our parents having the traditional roles.
Do you feel that there's any way that this can change or is changing or
families today, parents, they're still socializing their children with those roles of being male, being female.
I think it is changing.
I think that you can see evidence of that, for example, in mass media.
Shows like Sesame Street, for example, I think are a good illustration of that.
Although you see some vestiges, of course, of that.
So in Sesame Street, which I think is a fairly good illustration because so many kids watch it, you have in there
female characters who are mechanics or fix-it shops and things like that, so that you do see some movement away from the traditional stereotyping.
Although you can still notice, even in Sesame Street, which is supposed to be sort of a bastion of liberality for children, that, for example, the puppets, the characters, are almost entirely male.
So, I mean, I think things are changing.
I'm just not sure how fast they're changing.
And you see differences in...
in curriculum attention paid to those kinds of issues and so forth.
Now, I'm talking about mostly public kinds of education.
Of course, there are growing interest in religious kinds of education, some of which may stress sexual equality and some of which do not at all and emphasize traditional.
So I don't know.
I think overall, there's a growing awareness of those kinds of issues.
in terms of socialization.
So I think it is changing, maybe in general, although there are these pockets.
And as I said, I mean, I suppose we could do some studies on that.
Maybe it's just because I wish that that's what was happening.
Do you think it'll help with more women getting into the workforce and their children seeing their mother and their father working and that they will be more socialized to equality?
They both can work.
Mom's not staying at home.

Sure, although if you look at the studies, and Liz will talk about this, and sure, if you look at the studies, it is still the case that the people who do the cleaning at the house and do those other things are the women, regardless of whether they work or not.
So we still have some of the, sort of like the worst of both worlds.
You go and you work, and then you come home and you're expected by whoever to cook and clean and take care of the kids.
Women still spend most time
with the children probably, most time cleaning the house, most time cooking, and most time doing the shopping.
So yeah, I think that may change, maybe, the stereotypes.
But we might see them replaced by a whole new series of stereotypes that were maybe just as detrimental in some ways.
Do you feel it is more stressful on women to have a job and a family?
I think it's stressful in one way, in terms of time.
But I think in another way,
It helps deal with stress.

I mean, I think that if you, you know, I was talking about that before, if you're not forced into the job market, that's a different issue than being forced in where you, let's say you're the sole provider and there are lots of families like that, and so you have to make money and you have to take care of everything else.
That's a very stressful situation.
And now, if you're not forced into that situation where you are working, let's say, to supplement the income,
and you have the family, then I think that the stress will sort of relieve itself in some ways, although time is always very stressful.
But for a lot of women, the choice is not there.
They have to work.
They have to maintain the family.
Okay.
Well, I have no further questions.
Is there anything that you would like to add or something that you would like to say that I have not?
I don't think so.
Well, thank you for your time.
Okay.
One other question.
Why did you marry?
Because some people think that marriage is a form of servitude.
Well, I don't consider my marriage a form of servitude, although a lot of, and some feminists...

literature marriage is considered at least traditional marriage is considered to be a form of servitude because originally of course if you look at it historically women were considered erotic property and so that was the whole the whole phenomenon of marriage was sort of built up around that idea of property women as property and so I think it used to be yes a form of servitude and many times now I think it's a form of servitude but I don't think personally my own marriage is a form of servitude I think it's you know frankly I think
living together and getting married, there's not much difference between that.
It's just that we enjoy each other and we want to build our futures together.
And of course, since we have a child, that was important.
But I think the child was more of a commitment than a piece of paper that says that you're married.
So in other words, I don't think being married really has anything to do with it.
I think it's just the state of living together with someone and committing yourself to someone.
OK.
Did you accept your husband's name, or what name do you go by?
I go by what's known as my maiden name.
It's kind of a strange name.
And I did that for a number of reasons.
One is I was fairly old when I got married, and I'd had that name an awful long time, so I couldn't see changing it.
I'd published under my name.
before, and that's sometimes a problem for professional women if you change your name after you've published under one name.
And it just didn't make sense to me to take my husband's name.
I don't, you know, some people are very
staunch about not taking someone's name or taking it.
To me, I really don't see that it's all that important, quite frankly.
The name that I have now is my father's name, and some people say, well, see, it's because of the way names are passed down, that that's wrong, too.
And so some women have gone back and done other kinds of things, but the problem, of course, is going back to what name would be considered

female type of name because if you say well take my grandmother's name of course that was your grandmother's father's name and all those kinds of issues so you know as far as tradition that's just the way the tradition has passed in our society I I think it becomes problematic when you have children and then you decide what you're going to name them and the tradition is still to name them after the husband usually or the father
In our case, by the way, we couldn't decide what to do, and our little girl has my name.
That was just sort of a choice that we decided at the last moment.
But, I mean, that becomes a dilemma.
Some people have chosen hyphenated names, which is a nice kind of solution to that.
But I think that becomes a practical problem because then when your child grows up and then marries, you have to decide which names you're going to drop and so forth.
So, I mean, it's a big sort of an issue.
